Award.AwardTitle: US Ignite: Collaborative Research: Track 1: Industrial Cloud Robotics across Software Defined Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Currently, industrial robots are cost-effective for repetitive and high-volume tasks such as welding and painting, but not for lower-volume, mixed-part production. The need for robotic part handling for unstructured industrial applications is diverse. In manufactured-goods distribution centers, where multiple bins are presented to an operator, a human is required to handle a range of parts that must be boxed and shipped. In the reclamation and recycling industry, humans sort waste streams of mixed products on conveyor belts. Assembly and kitting operations in manufacturing are termed ?robotic opportunities? but they require a solution for handling many part types in the same work-cell. This project will research and integrate technologies to enable the use of industrial robots for low-volume mixed-part production tasks. The proposed solution will include 3D image sensors and high-speed flexible networking, cloud computing, and industrial robots. The inclusion of cutting-edge new software such as the Robot-Operating System Industrial (ROS-I) and Cloud Computing platforms offer excellent educational opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students. The software developed in this project will be widely distributed to enable further innovations by other teams.

The project objective is to develop cloud robotics applications that leverage high-performance computing and high-speed software-defined networks (SDN). Specifically, the target applications combine big-data analytics of sensor data (of the type collected from factory floors) with the control of industrial robots for low-volume, mixed-part production tasks. Cloud computers located at a remote facility relative to the factory floor on which industrial robots operate can be used for compute-intensive applications such as object identification from 3D sensor data, and grasp planning for the robots to perform object manipulation. The project methods will consist of (i) integrating ROS-I components and developing new software as required to transmit the 3D sensor data to remote computers, running the object identification and grasp planning applications, and returning robot instructions to the original site, (ii) running this software on geographically distributed compute clouds, (iii) collecting measurements and enhancing the software to meet real-time delay requirements. The technical challenge lies in meeting these stringent real-time requirements. For example, high-speed networks with the flexibility to connect arbitrary factory floors and datacenters are needed to transfer the 3D sensor data quickly to the remote cloud computers and to deliver the computed robot instructions(hence, SDN).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project objective is to develop and support cloud robotics applications that leverage high-performance computing and high-speed software-defined networks. Specifically, the target applications combine big-data analytics of sensor data, e.g., data collected from factory floors, with the control of industrial robots for low-volume, mixed-part production tasks. Cloud servers located at a remote facility relative to the factory floor on which industrial robots operate can be used for compute-intensive applications such as object identification from 3D sensor data, and grasp planning for the robots to perform object manipulation.

The project main outcomes include:

a)       Multiple robotics applications, including Godel and Gilbreth. The Godel surface blending application requires a robot arm controlled by a set of software modules running on multiple servers in a distributed fashion, connected using an SDN enabled network to the robot arm. Gilbreth is an application for autonomously picking up and sorting objects of different types from a moving conveyor belt and sorting the objects into bins according to their type.

b)      Investigation and experimental demonstration of radio communication technology that makes use of unlicensed spectrum. In collaboration with Texas Instruments, the UTD team designed an improved radio channel hopping algorithm that improves the network connectivity and stability of the IEEE 802.15.4e-TSCH standard.

c)       Investigation and experimental demonstration of radio communication technology that makes use of licensed spectrum, i.e., Cloud-based 5G technology. A testbed was created at UTD to integrate: 5G technology, Software Defined Networking, Programmable Optical Networks, and industrial applications.

d)      Investigation and experimental demonstration of Virtual Machines (VMs) and docker containers controlled through OpenStack to automatically assign ROS modules to available servers. In conjunction with this outcome, the UTD team investigated the use of Virtual Machine (VM) and docker live-migration between geo-diverse Cloud servers, a technique that has the potential to offer load balancing of resource utilization and resiliency in the presence of a disaster at a given compute location when running decentralized applications, like the ROS-based Godel surface blending application and the robotics pick-and-sort Gilbreth application.

e)      Outreach: while UTD, UVA, and SwRI are the project leads, external participants contributed to the project, e.g., Keio University in Japan. A number of students, both undergraduate and graduate, were actively involved in the project and were trained in the above cutting-edge technologies.

 

This project leveraged the following resources:

Robot Operating System (ROS) - Industrial (ROS-I) software: ROS-I builds on the popular open source ROS software platform, which is used for service and other types of robots in academic research laboratories. ROS-I consists of a set of middleware components and packages that enables a distributed implementation of robotics software-based applications.

High-speed Software Defined Networking (SDN) infrastructure: e.g., Internet2?s Advanced Layer-2 Service (AL2S), campus CC-NIE and Dynamic Network System (DYNES), Layer-2 services from regional network providers, and PROnet (Programmable Optical Network) the optical Research and Education Network at UTD.

Off-the-shelf network equipment, including:

a)       DWDM flex grid Reconfigurable Optical Add Drop Multiplexing (ROADM) nodes offering Colorless, Directionless, and Contention-less, (CDC) functionalities, combined with Ethernet switches to form a flexible two-layer network infrastructure;

b)      Software Defined Radios (SDR) to implement the wireless portion of the 5G infrastructure.

Existing dark fiber already in the field and being installed by UTD Information Technology Office.

High performance compute facilities, e.g., CloudLab and ExoGENI racks for high-speed computing. Additionally, UTD has received an InstaGENI rack, hosted at the Flexential (www.flexential.com) site in Richardson, off our main campus. UTD has also received a number of HPC racks, formerly part of the TACC Stampede supercomputing center in Austin. Three of these racks are operational and hosted at the Flexential site. Two half-racks are in the electrical engineering building research lab on campus.

 

Impact on the development of the principal discipline(s) of the project

Demonstrating that industrial applications like Godel surface blending and Gilbreth object pick-and-sort, can be carried out by a robot arm at a location, while ?the intelligence? software modules of the application are being executed at other locations, away from the production floor, has a significant impact on advance manufacturing architectural solutions. The production floor does not have to host powerful and industrial-grade servers. The servers executing the CPU or other specialized hardware intensive tasks can instead be stored away, in the Cloud, lowering the CAPEX and OPEX costs incurred.

The UTD team was able to experimentally demonstrate the resilience of a Cloud-native solution for industrial automation. Resilience is achieved by resorting to geo-diverse data centers which are interconnected by a metro or even wide-area optical network. We demonstrated industrial applications, such as the Godel surface blending, are not adversely affected by the recovery procedures. This shows that the reliability of Cloud-native advanced manufacturing solutions can be significantly improved by leveraging automated procedures based on both network virtualization and software defined networking approaches compared to more conventional data communication techniques.
